awd_titl_txt: Early Emergence of Socioeconomic Disparities in Mathematical Understanding
awd_abstract_narration:
The math skills of children from high income families have grown faster than those of children from middle- or low-income families resulting in a significant and persistent gap. These disparities emerge in preschool and are larger by the start of kindergarten. As children progress through school, the gap in math skills persists or even widens. Importantly, SES-related disparities in math skills have implications for long-term academic achievement and educational attainment, as well as access to STEM education and professions in adulthood. As such, there is an urgent need to identify the factors shaping early math development before children start formal schooling. This investigation will provide foundational knowledge about the activities and interactions in the home environment that drive the early emergence of math skills disparities related to SES. In the long term, findings from this work could inform home visitation programs and early care and education curricula aimed at strengthening the early math skills of children living in low resourced communities. The knowledge generated by this study has the potential to enhance equity in access to STEM education and professions for all children. 
 
Using a longitudinal sequential study of two cohorts of socioeconomically diverse 30-month-olds (N = 320) and their parents, the proposed study will strengthen knowledge of the etiology of SES disparities in math skills by addressing three aims. First, it will examine associations between the home learning environment (HLE) and early math skills. Second, it will describe  SES disparities in HLE and their implications for math learning. Third, it will test family stress and family culture as pathways through which SES shapes HLE and early math skills. Children will complete assessments of early math skills and other general cognitive abilities at age 30 months and again around 42-47 months. In addition to the child assessments at 30 months, in-home structured observations with a parent, parent surveys, and time diaries will measure the quantity and quality of children's opportunities for math learning at home. To measure family stress, parents will complete questionnaires assessing general stress as well as stress specifically related to performing and teaching math. To measure family culture, parents will complete questionnaires assessing their general and math-specific parenting beliefs and observations of family interactions will be conducted. This study will test whether domain-general and math-specific family stress and culture mediate the relation between HLE and SES. In sum, this study will make contributions to understanding the early emergence of economic disparities in early math skills. Theoretically, it will delineate whether domain-general or math-specific differences in HLE explain disparities in early math skills related to socioeconomic status. It will advance research by concurrently considering the roles of stress and culture in shaping disparities in children's opportunity to learn math in their early home environments. This project is funded by the EHR Core Research program, which emphasizes STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Children’s early math learning involves a wide array of different skills, including counting objects, arithmetic, identifying patterns, and knowledge of shapes and spatial relations among objects, and variability in children’s early math skills relates to families’ socioeconomic background. This study was designed to examine whether SES differences in early math skills emerged as early as 2 or 3 years of age, and if so, why. To understand why and how SES may be influencing early math skills, we focused on several potential mechanisms, including learning-related activities and conversations in the home environment, as well as general and math-specific sources of family stress, beliefs, and attitudes.

To address these goals, we recruited high, middle, and low SES families in urban, suburban, and rural areas surrounding Pittsburgh to understand how parents were supporting early math learning with their toddlers. Over 4 years (2020-2024), 322 families participated in two recorded zoom calls when children were 2 years of age (28-38 months old), and again 12 months later when children were 3 years old. We observed parent-child interactions during playful learning activities, interviewed parents about their daily routines using time diaries, and surveyed parents about their income and education, home activities, stress, attitudes, and beliefs. In addition, we assessed children’s early math skills.

Our first set of findings involved identifying key aspects of toddlers’ early learning experiences at home that supported their math skills. We found strong associations between the frequency of math activities reported on parent surveys and the diversity of types of math activities endorsed in time diary interviews. However, parent talk about math during the observations of playful learning were generally unrelated to parents’ reports of engagement at home in math activities in either surveys or time diaries. Several of these home math environment measures were positively correlated with toddlers’ math skills. Since past research has demonstrated that both home math activities and parent math talk predict children’s math skills, our results stress the need for multimethod studies that differentiate these early learning opportunities.

Next, we carefully documented toddlers’ emerging mathematical skills using novel tasks. Specifically, we showed that toddlers may understand number words before they can produce appropriate sets of objects (e.g., they understand “two” but do not accurately give two objects when asked) suggesting that children’s number word comprehension develops gradually.

We also showed SES-related differences in toddlers’ math skills. Importantly, observational measures of toddlers’ self-regulation skills significantly explained some of the association between SES and children’s math (and language) skills. In contrast, parent reports of children’s self-regulation skills were not uniquely related to SES or children’s early math and language skills, underscoring the need for careful consideration of how self-regulation is measured among toddlers when examining its associations with pre-academic skills.

Last, we examined the extent to which parents’ stress, beliefs and attitudes contributed to their reports of math-related learning activities in the home, as well as their observed talk about math concepts during their playful interactions with their toddlers. We found that a broad range of parent characteristics, including parents’ beliefs about the importance of math, math growth mindset beliefs, math anxiety, and past math coursework, predicted how frequently they engaged in number-related activities with their toddlers. More frequent engagement in number activities at home were associated with better number skills for young children. Parents’ math beliefs, attitudes, and past coursework experiences were all predictive of more number-related activities occurring at home, which in turn predicted toddlers’ higher number skills.

Collectively, this NSF funded project yielded several key products on toddlers developing understanding of math concepts. The Intellectual Merit includes: (1) examining SES-related variability in 2- and 3- year-old children's emerging math skills; (2) in-depth examination of young children's home learning environments, which combines structured observations of parent-child interactions, questionnaires, and time diaries to predict direct assessments of children's emerging math skills; (3) Collection of in-depth assessments of children’s early self-regulatory skills have allowed us to consider whether this core competency relates to the earliest emergence of SES differences in children’s math skills; and (4) data sharing videos with authorized investigators on the video-repository Databrary to advance the science of early math learning. Broader Impacts include: (1) significant methodological contributions to the literature with the development of valid and reliable measures of children's numeracy, spatial, and language skills at ages 2 and 3 that can successfully be administered online to a socioeconomically and racially/ethnically diverse sample of families; (2) demonstration that structured parent-child interactions and parent math and reading assessments can be successfully adapted to the online format; (3) and wide-ranging research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows who gained expertise on direct assessments, interviewing, behavioral coding, analysis, and scientific writing for conferences and publications.
